div.div: 1. We have to generate the ssh keys, the defualt algo to generate keys is ed25519 but we can also specify different algo using -t flag, and the defualt name of the keys will be algo name and defualt path is home/.ssh folder but we can also specify custom name with custom path using -f flag and defualt format is openSSH format but can specify the different format also using -m flag and -C flag to set comment at the end for public key

div.div: 1. When connecting to ssh server we need server's username and public IP address and port number, defulat is 22 but can specify different port using -p flag on which server is running and to make our device as ssh server we need to start cmd sshd means "secure shell daemon"

switch.text: SSH Port Forwarding/Tunneling

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 333px; margin-left: 635px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0; text-align: left; max-height: 111px; overflow: hidden; color: #000000;

div.div:
1. Local port forwarding: - a port running on server can not be accessed in our local machine port, so we can tunnell this server port with our local machine port using ssh -L flag and then directly access those remote service within our machine
eg: - if we want any remote running database within our local project

switch.text: 1. Local port forwarding: - a port running on server...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 312px; height: 1px; padding-top: 425px; margin-left: 635px;

div.div: 2. Remote port forwarding: - This means that we can forward our local machine port to remote server port using ssh -R flag, that can be access from anywhere in the world via sever's public IP + port number

switch.text: 2. Remote port forwarding: - This means that we can...

div.div:
1. OpenSSH format: - this is most common format used today, native for linux.unix macOS and in window 10/11.
Uses standard OpenSSH format, extension if often .pem (optional, legacy) SSH format and no extension

switch.text: 1. OpenSSH format: - this is most common format us...

div.div:
2. puTTY format: - user friendly GUI tool for window.
Uses PPK (PuTTY Private Key) format. extension is .ppk

switch.text: 2. puTTY format: - user friendly GUI tool for wind...

div.div:
3. RFC4716/SECSH Format: - Used by SSH2 protocol standard
Extension is .pub, .ssh2 only for public key
